column1: Caffeine is a substance that is found in certain plants.
Caffeine may be used for the short-term relief of fatigue or drowsiness.

It is found naturally in the leaves, seeds, and fruits of more than 60 plants, including: - Tea leaves - Kola nuts - Coffee - Cocoa beans It is also found in processed foods: - Coffee - 100 mg per cup - Tea - 14 mg to 60 mg per cup - Chocolate - 45 mg in 1.5 oz. bar - Most colas (unless they are labeled "caffeine-free") - 45 mg in 12 oz. drink - Candies, energy drinks, snacks, gum - 40 to 100 mg per serving Caffeine is often added to over-the-counter medications such as pain relievers, over-the-counter diet pills, and cold medicines.

Caffeine can lead to: - A fast heart rate - Anxiety - Depression - Difficulty sleeping - Nausea - Restlessness - Tremors - Urinating more often - Vomiting Stopping caffeine suddenly may cause withdrawal symptoms.
- Large amounts of caffeine may stop the absorption of calcium and lead to thinning bones (osteoporosis).
- Caffeine may lead to painful, lumpy breasts (fibrocystic disease).

- Four 8 oz. cups of brewed or drip coffee (about 400 mg of caffeine) or 5 servings of caffeinated soft drinks or tea (about 165 to 235 mg of caffeine) per day is an average or moderate amount of caffeine for most people.
(However, it should be noted that 5 servings of regular soft drinks is over 700 calories and can contribute to obesity.)
- You are a woman with painful, lumpy breasts.
Caffeine is a stimulant and a hyperactive child may need to avoid it.
Caffeine is a stimulant, so it increases your heart rate and metabolism.
- During pregnancy, 300 mg of caffeine a day may increase the risk of miscarriage.
Many drugs will interact with caffeine.
